text:
I have discussed this matter on user@ant.apache.org without any luck.

I have increased  Xmx and Xms with different values ( see below).

ANT_OPTS="-Xms256M -Xmx512M";export ANT_OPTS

I have also been using JFluid profiler to see which target ( task) that 
causes  ant to give java.lang.OutOfMemoryError.

I have isolated the <junitreport> task as the sole source to this problem.
When debugging ant it becomes, AFAIK, that the parsing of all the xml files
makes the java.lang.OutOfMemoryError to be thrown.

The implementation of <junitreport> seems very memory intensive. Is it not 
possible to have an attribute that selects whether to use SAX or DOM when 
parsing? 


This is my target in the build.xml
----------------------------------
<target name="test:junit:report"  depends="init" description="generate junit 
reports">
   <junitreport todir="${test.reports.dir}">
    <!--<fileset dir="${test.reports.dir}">-->
        <fileset dir="${coverage.dir}">
	<include name="TEST-*.xml"/>
    </fileset>
    <report format="frames" todir="${test.reports.dir}/html"/>
  </junitreport>
  </target>

These are the files that we parse
---------------------------------

java.lang.OutOfMemoryError
creator: mikael.petterson@ericsson.com
bodewig@apache.org
text:
<junitreport> doesn't actually parse anything - well, it loads the files.

Antt passes the files to the XSLT processor after aggregating them into one big
file.  Most probably Ant does not die during the aggregation but the XSLT processor
needs more memory than it gets.  Which processor do you use?  Using a different
one like Saxon instead of Xalan-J or just Xalan-J instead of Xalan-XSLTC (the
default processor of Java 5.0) might help.

creator: gzoldi@movaris.com
text:
Encounter similar problem but was able to resolve the issue by creating a 
system environment variable ANT_OPTS= -Xms256M -Xmx512M

Mikael, are you running on Java1.5? It looks like the built in xslt engine is
more memory-hungry than the classic xalan one...
creator: stevel@apache.org
stevel@apache.org
text:
I'm going to close this as wontfix. the XSL transforms are very memory hungry,
especially if you dont add xalan2 to the classpath.

the only way to fix it is to not use XSL to process things.
